1.Q: What does hurricane formation mainly depend on?
1.A: Warm water mixing with cold water in the ocean
1.B: Warm and cold fronts mixing in the air
1.IncorrectFeedback: Try thinking about where hurricanes usually form in the ocean
1.CorrectFeedback: Warm ocean temperatures provides energy for hurricane formation

2.Q: What is the most dangerous aspect of hurricanes if you live near the coast?
2.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: this factor also causes the most damage for coastal communities
2.CorrectFeedback: The storm surge threatens coastal areas with severe flooding

3.Q: What is the minimum windspeed needed for a storm to be considered a hurricane?
3.IncorrectFeedback: Think about the minimum windspeed a hurricane must hold
3.CorrectFeedback: Hurricanes are classified as having 74+ mph winds

4.Q: What is the difference between hurricanes and cyclones?
4.A: Nothing, they are different names for the same weather phenomenon
4.B: Hurricanes form around the equator while cyclones form at higher latitudes
4.C: Hurricanes have faster windspeeds than cyclones
4.D: Cyclones only have windspeeds of less than 100 mph
4.IncorrectFeedback: Can you think of any differences?
4.CorrectFeedback: The different terms are used depending on where the storm formed

5.Q: When does a tropical storm become a hurricane?
5.A: When the waves carried by the hurricane reach 2 meters in height
5.C: When its sustained windspeed reaches or exceeds 74 mph
5.D: When the atmospheric pressure of the storm drops below 1000 milibars
5.IncorrectFeedback: What is the deciding factor meteorologists use to classify these storms?
5.CorrectFeedback: The cutoff between hurricane and tropical storm occurs at 74 mph

6.Q: Which quadrant(s) of hurricanes, if any, typically have the fastest windspeeds?
6.A: All quadrants typically have similar windspeeds
6.B: The front half of the storm
6.IncorrectFeedback: One quadrant of hurricanes usually has higher windspeeds
6.CorrectFeedback: The forward motion of the entire storm adds to the windspeed in the forward right quadrant

7.Q: How deep does moving water have to be to sweep a grown adult off their feet?
7.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: It does not take much moving water to carry away large objects
7.CorrectFeedback: An adult human can be carried away by as little as 6 inches of fast-moving water!

8.Q: How deep does moving water have to be to sweep away an average car?
8.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: It does not take much moving water to carry away large objects
8.CorrectFeedback: Average cars start being swept away with around 18 inches of moving water. Trucks and SUVs do not fare much better

9.Q: What is not a danger associated with hurricanes events?
9.B: Damaged power lines and building infrastructure
9.D: Objects being carried by fast winds
9.IncorrectFeedback: This is one of the dangers posed during hurricane events
9.CorrectFeedback: High temperatures are not necessarily associated with hurricanes, unless damaged power lines or electronics starts a fire

10.Q: How much water does a typical hurricane drop on a region?
10.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: Not every hurricane floods a region, consider all hurricanes
10.CorrectFeedback: An average hurricane will drop around 6-12 inches of rain over an area

11.Q: What part of a hurricane has the strongest wind and rain?
11.A: The cloud bands around the eye of the hurricane
11.B: The cloud bands at the front edge of the hurricane that hit land first
11.C: The cloud bands at the back edge of the hurricane
11.D: Inside the eye of the hurricane
11.IncorrectFeedback: Consider at which part of the hurricane are the clouds bands the densest
11.CorrectFeedback: The clouds around the eye of the storm will carry the fastest winds and heaviest rains

12.Q: How are hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico affected during El nino years?
12.A: The warmer ocean temperatures in the eastern Pacific have no affect on hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean
12.B: There are more hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico
12.C: There are less hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico
12.D: There are less hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean but more in the Gulf of Mexico
12.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: Although ocean temperatures are warmer in the eastern Pacific, wind patterns over the Atlantic are changed during El nino
12.CorrectFeedback: There are actually less hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico during El nino due to increased vertical wind shear weakening hurricane formation

13.Q: What surface ocean temperature (in Fahrenheit) is required for hurricane development?
13.IncorrectFeedback: A lower surface ocean temperature can help hurricanes form
13.CorrectFeedback: At around 80 degrees Fahrenheit surface ocean temperatures can feed hurricanes energy

14.Q: How many tropical storms develop over the Atlantic Ocean during a typical hurricane season?
14.IncorrectFeedback: Consider how many tropical storm events you hear about during an average hurricane season
14.CorrectFeedback: Around 10 tropical storms will develop over the Atlantic Ocean, including the Caribbean Sea and Gulf of Mexico
